intro: Mentha gentilis var. rivalis, commonly known as field mint, is a perennial herb native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with opposite, lance-shaped leaves that have a strong minty fragrance. Its small, tubular flowers are usually pale blue to purple and appear in whorls along the stems. This variety is often used in traditional medicine and as a culinary herb due to its refreshing scent and medicinal properties.
